Write a cold LinkedIn message to a recruiter at Google for a Software Engineer position

**Subject:** SWE Role - Referred by [Mutual Connection] / Found via [Source]

---

Hi [Recruiter Name],

I came across Google's SWE openings and wanted to reach out directly rather than just applying into the void.

**Quick background:**
• 4 years at [Current Company] building distributed systems
• Led migration to Kubernetes, reduced deployment time by 70%
• Published paper on ML optimization at [Conference]

I'm particularly excited about [specific Google team/product] because [genuine reason connected to your experience].

Would you be open to a quick chat about the team's current priorities? Happy to share my resume if there's a potential fit.

Thanks,
[Your Name]

---

**Why this works:**
- Specific achievements with metrics
- Shows you researched the company
- Asks for conversation, not a job
- Easy to say yes to (low commitment ask)
- 97 words - respects their time

Write a follow-up email after no response to my job application (1 week ago)

**Subject:** Following Up: [Position Title] Application - [Your Name]

---

Hi [Hiring Manager/Recruiter Name],

I submitted my application for the [Position Title] role last week and wanted to follow up with a quick note.

Since applying, I've been thinking about how my experience with [specific skill] could help with [company's known challenge or initiative]. For example, at my current role, I [one-sentence achievement relevant to the job].

I'd love the opportunity to discuss how I could contribute to [team/company]. Is there a good time for a brief call this week?

I've attached my resume for convenience.

Best regards,
[Your Name]
[Phone]
[LinkedIn URL]

---

**Pro tips:**
- Send on Tuesday-Thursday, 9-11 AM their time zone
- Reference something new (recent company news, your continued research)
- Don't apologize for following up - it shows interest
- One follow-up is professional; three is pushy
- If no response after 2nd follow-up, move on

Write a LinkedIn connection request to someone at my dream company (not a recruiter)

**Connection Request (300 characters max):**

---

Hi [Name], I've been following [Company]'s work on [specific project/product]. As someone building similar solutions at [Your Company], I'd love to connect and learn more about your team's approach. No ask - just genuinely interested in your work!

---

**After they accept - Follow-up message:**

Thanks for connecting, [Name]!

I've been diving into [Company]'s [specific blog post/talk/product] and was impressed by [specific detail]. Quick question if you have a moment:

[One specific, easy-to-answer question about their work]

No pressure if you're busy - I know how it is. Either way, looking forward to following your updates!

---

**Why this works:**
- Shows genuine interest in THEIR work, not just what they can do for you
- Specific reference proves you did research
- "No ask" removes pressure
- Opens door for future conversation
- When you eventually mention you're job hunting, they already know you

**Don't do this:**
- "I'd love to pick your brain" (overused, sounds extractive)
- "Can you refer me?" (way too soon)
- "I'm looking for jobs at [Company]" (in first message)

Write a cold email to a startup CEO/founder about a job (no openings posted)

**Subject:** Quick idea for [Company] + potential collaboration

---

Hi [Founder Name],

I saw your recent [tweet/podcast/article] about [specific topic they discussed]. Your point about [specific insight] really resonated - I've been working on exactly that problem at [Current Company].

**The short version:**
I'm a [Your Role] who's helped [impressive achievement in 1 line]. I've been watching [Company] since [specific milestone] and think my experience in [relevant skill] could help with your [growth/scaling/specific challenge].

**I'm not just job hunting** - I genuinely think there's a fit. I put together a few ideas on [specific value you could add].

Worth a 15-minute call to explore?

[Your Name]
[One-line proof of credibility]

---

**Alternative for very early startups:**

Hi [Name],

I know you're probably not hiring formally yet, but I wanted to plant a seed.

I've been building [relevant thing] at [Current Company] for [X] years, and I'm specifically interested in [Company] because [genuine reason].

When the time comes to grow the team, I'd love to be considered. Until then, happy to be helpful in any way - intros, feedback on product, etc.

No response needed - just wanted to get on your radar.

[Your Name]

---

**Why this works:**
- "Quick idea" subject line gets opened
- Shows you follow their content
- Offers value, not just asks for a job
- "Not just job hunting" reframes the conversation
- Short, scannable, easy to respond to

Write a thank you email after a job interview

**Subject:** Thank you - [Position] Interview

---

Hi [Interviewer Name],

Thank you for taking the time to speak with me today about the [Position] role. I really enjoyed learning about [specific thing discussed - team structure, project, challenge].

Our conversation about [specific topic] got me even more excited about the opportunity. I've been thinking about your question on [topic you want to reinforce], and I wanted to add:

[1-2 sentences adding value or clarifying something from the interview]

I'm confident that my experience in [key skill] and [another skill] would allow me to [specific contribution to their goal].

Please don't hesitate to reach out if you need any additional information. I look forward to hearing about next steps.

Best regards,
[Your Name]

---

**Timing:**
- Send within 2-4 hours of interview
- If interviewed with multiple people, personalize each email
- Reference something unique from each conversation

**Panel interview variation:**
- Send to each interviewer individually
- Reference specific question/topic from each person
- If you don't have all emails, ask recruiter or check LinkedIn

**What NOT to include:**
- "I think the interview went well" (let them judge)
- Salary discussion (not the place)
- "I really need this job" (desperation)
- Excessive flattery

Write a networking message to ask for an informational interview

**LinkedIn Message:**

---

Hi [Name],

I came across your profile while researching [industry/company/role]. Your path from [their previous role] to [current role] is really interesting - it's similar to the transition I'm trying to make.

I'm currently a [Your Role] at [Company], exploring opportunities in [target field]. I'd love to learn:

• How you made the transition to [their field]
• What skills were most valuable in your journey
• Any advice for someone in my position

Would you have 20 minutes for a virtual coffee in the next couple of weeks? I promise to come prepared and respect your time.

Thanks for considering,
[Your Name]

---

**Email version (if you have their email):**

**Subject:** Quick Question from a Fellow [Industry] Professional

Hi [Name],

I hope this email finds you well. I'm [Your Name], a [Your Role] at [Company], and I'm reaching out because [specific reason you chose them].

I'm in the early stages of exploring a transition to [target role/industry], and your background in [specific experience] is exactly the perspective I'm seeking.

Would you be open to a brief 15-20 minute call to share your experience? I have specific questions prepared and won't take more time than needed.

I'm flexible on timing and happy to work around your schedule.

Best,
[Your Name]
[LinkedIn] (so they can vet you)

---

**After they agree - Confirmation email:**

Thank you so much for making time, [Name]! I've blocked [Day, Time] on my calendar.

Here's a quick preview of what I'd love to discuss:
1. [Specific question about their career path]
2. [Question about skills/industry]
3. [Question about how to break in]

Looking forward to it!

[Your Name]

---

**Why this gets responses:**
- Specific reason for reaching out
- Time-bounded ask (20 min, not "pick your brain")
- Shows you've done research
- Offers flexibility
- Clear what they'll discuss (not vague)
